title: 115_s1392
content: The Act may be cited as the "Public-Private Partnership Advisory Council to End Human Trafficking Act". Congress finds that an estimated 20.9 million people are enslaved in human trafficking worldwide, with slavery being a $150 billion industry. The Department of State defines trafficking in persons as the act of recruiting, harboring, transporting, providing, or obtaining a person for compelled labor or commercial sex acts through force, fraud, or coercion. Approximately 2 million enslaved individuals are children forced into sex slavery, with child sex slaves facing rape as many as 10 to 15 times per night. Although many developed regions and countries meet the standards of the Trafficking Victims Protection Act (TVPA), there are developing countries that do not attempt to meet these standards or lack the necessary resources for effective anti-trafficking measures. Slavery is illegal worldwide, yet it persists in every country, with no country immune to the consequences of modern slavery. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The Council refers to the Public-Private Partnership Advisory Council to End Human Trafficking, the Group is the Senior Policy Operating Group under the Trafficking Victims Protection Act, and the Task Force is the President's Interagency Task Force to Combat Trafficking. SEC. 4. PUBLIC-PRIVATE PARTNERSHIP ADVISORY COUNCIL TO END HUMAN TRAFFICKING. The Public-Private Partnership Advisory Council to End Human Trafficking is established to provide advice and recommendations to the Group and Task Force. The Council will consist of 8 to 14 representatives from NGOs and nonprofit groups with expertise in anti-human trafficking and victim rehabilitation. Members should reflect the diverse backgrounds of public-private partnerships for anti-trafficking. The President appoints members to the Council for anti-trafficking efforts, rehabilitation, and aftercare of trafficking victims. Appointments include consultation with Senate and House leaders. The Council members serve 2-year terms and can be reappointed for an additional term. They are not considered federal government employees and do not receive compensation. The Council advises the Group on combating human trafficking and meets at least annually to review related policies and programs. The Council advises the Group on combating human trafficking, formulates assessments and recommendations, and meets annually to present findings and recommendations. The Council advises the Group on combating human trafficking and presents findings and recommendations annually. The Council is not subject to the Federal Advisory Committee Act. SEC. 5. REPORTS. The Council must submit annual reports to various Senate and House committees, as well as the Task Force chair, containing findings from reviews conducted under section 3(c)(2). The Council must submit annual reports to Senate and House committees, the Task Force chair, and the Group members. The Council will terminate on September 30, 2020.
